awd_abstract_narration:
Michael Gruenwald at the University of Utah is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods (CTMC) Program in the Chemistry Division to perform theoretical and computational research on the crystallization of chiral molecules. Objects are called chiral if they cannot be superimposed with their mirror images -- just like the left and right hands of humans.  Many molecules such as amino acids (in DNA) and sugars that are important for the functions of the human body are chiral. They exist in right-handed and left-handed pairs, called enantiomers.  Notably, when it comes to medicine, only one enantiomer is wanted in many drug applications.  Often one chiral form is beneficial and the other may have no activity or may be harmful. Laboratory syntheses of drugs frequently result only in mixtures, and it is difficult and costly to separate enantiomers. For a small fraction of drug molecules, crystallization can be used to produce solids from solution that contain only one of the enantiomers.  Crystallization, when it works, separates entantiomers cheaply and efficiently. The Gruenwald research group is exploring separations that use crystallization to understand how they are guided by such aspects as molecular shape and interaction forces. Computational models are being developed to help predict when crystallization to form pure enantiomers will happen; This understanding has great potential value for drug development and other chemical syntheses. The models at the heart of this work are used in extensive educational outreach to introduce chemical principles to young students. An educational workshop is being created that leverages the strong visual connections between chiral molecules, their crystal structures, and artwork by M.C. Escher.

Research supported by this award aims to understand why racemic or other mixtures of chiral molecules in solution spontaneously form enantiopure crystals. Molecular models and computational methods are being developed to reveal the driving forces and guiding principles for the formation of both enantiopure and racemic crystals. Computationally efficient models are used to consider a broad range of molecular shapes and interactions within molecular dynamics computer simulations, including specific methods of trajectory sampling as well as coarse-graining. Large data sets of computational crystallization experiments are created, and models will be characterized according to their propensity to form enantiopure or racemic crystals. Of particular interest is the development of computational methods that can enumerate all low-energy crystal structures of these models and thus determine the thermodynamic landscape for chiral crystallization. By determining distributions of small molecular clusters, fundamental differences in the nucleation dynamics of enantiopure and racemic crystals can be identified. Statistical models are being developed that allow one to predict the likelihood of enantiopure crystallization from knowledge of racemic and enantiopure crystal structures. One ultimate aim is to inform computational screening procedures to pre-determine the likelihood of a racemic mixture to separate and thus to allow the rational synthetic modification of molecules to enhance the separation. Another is for the molecular models and methods of crystal structure enumeration developed here to be useful for future studies of the self-assembly of chiral and non-chiral building blocks on different length scales, including proteins and inorganic nanostructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most medicinal drugs are delivered to the patient as pills, which contain crystals of the drug molecule. The specific crystal structure, which is the spatial pattern in which molecules are arranged, determines how quickly and how much of the drug is released in the human body. This research project was focused on a deceptively simple question: When molecules crystallize, what crystal structure will they form? Most drug molecules can form two or more different crystal structures and the same drug molecule can be highly effective in one crystal structure and essentially useless in another. As another complication, most drug molecules are chiral; they naturally exist in two versions (called enantiomers) that are non-identical mirror images of one another, just like a person's left and right hands. Only one of the two enantiomers has the desired effect in the body, the other either has no effect or can even be harmful. Chemists therefore need to find ways of forming crystals that only contain the "right" enantiomer. Unfortunately, most chiral molecules naturally form crystals that contain both enantiomers and special methods are often needed to separate enantiomers. For all these reasons, much time and resources are spent in the development of a new drug on exploring by trial-and-error what crystal structures the drug molecule can form and what the properties of these crystals are. 

For several decades, researchers have worked to replace these time and resource intensive crystal screenings with computer predictions. They have developed sophisticated computer programs that, given a particular molecule, can produce a list of up to hundreds of potential crystal structures. These candidate structures are then ranked according to their energy because thermodynamic principles dictate that the candidate structure with the lowest energy should crystallize. While such computer predictions have become more and more reliable over the years, they still have not replaced manual trial-and-error crystal searches. One important reason is that most computational predictions neglect the kinetics of crystal formation: crystals that do not have the lowest energy can still form in many cases if the microscopic process of assembling the crystal from its molecular pieces proceeds much faster than that of crystals with lower energy. In other cases, no crystal will form at all and molecules instead aggregate as disordered solids. Crystal structure ranking by energy, however, does not capture these effects and often fails to correctly predict crystallization outcomes.

Research performed under this award has resulted in new fundamental insights into the crystallization of chiral molecules. The research team has developed molecular models and computational techniques that, for the first time, allow for a detailed look at the interplay of thermodynamics and kinetics of crystallization for a large number of different model molecules. The results of this research point towards several ways of improving crystallization experiments and computer predictions. The research team has shown that crystallization depends sensitively on how different parts of a molecule, referred to as functional groups, interact with one another. If these interactions have different strength, some weak and some strong, molecules tend to crystallize better and tend to naturally form crystals containing only one of the two enantiomers, an outcome that is highly advantageous for drug development. If, however, interactions among functional groups are more uniform, crystallization often results in structures that contain both enantiomers or no crystal will form at all. These results can help chemists modify molecules or crystallization conditions in order to favor desired crystallization outcomes. But even if that is not an option, results of this project can help improve computational predictions of which crystal will form. The research team has shown that the outcome of an attempted crystallization of a particular molecule can be gleaned from how molecules behave in solution, before any crystal has started to form at all. Small aggregates of two, three, or more molecules in solution, so-called oligomers, hold the key to how fast or slow certain crystal structure will form. If oligomers in solution are structurally similar to pieces of a potential crystal structure, that crystal structure will have a kinetic advantage over other crystal structures and will have a larger likelihood of actually forming, even if there are other candidate structures with lower energy. A comparison of structural motifs that form in solution with structural motifs in the various computationally predicted crystal structures can therefore help to greatly improve energy-based crystal structure prediction. A main advantage of this procedure is that it is computationally fast compared to the cumbersome predictions and ranking of crystal structure candidates. The research team therefore anticipates that the results of this project will catalyze efforts to improve thermodynamics-based crystal structure prediction methods and reduce time and cost of developing new medicinal drugs.
